title: Edmund Hartley
text:
Colonel Edmund Baron Hartley <a href="Victoria%20Cross">VC</a> <a href="Order%20of%20St%20Michael%20and%20St%20George">CMG</a> (6 May 1847 – 20 March 1919) was a recipient of the <a href="Victoria%20Cross">Victoria Cross</a>, the highest and most prestigious award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a> and <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20Nations">Commonwealth</a> forces.
The deed.
Hartley was born in <a href="Ivybridge">Ivybridge</a>, <a href="Devon">Devon</a>, <a href="England">England</a>, on 6 May 1847. He was 32 years old, and a surgeon <a href="major">major</a> in the <a href="Cape%20Mounted%20Riflemen">Cape Mounted Riflemen</a>, <a href="Cape%20Colonial%20Forces">Cape Colonial Forces</a> during the <a href="Morosi">Morosi's Mountain 1879 Campaign</a> when the following deed took place for which he was awarded the VC.
On 5 June 1879 in <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>, Surgeon Major Hartley attended the wounded under fire at the unsuccessful attack at <a href="Morosi%27s%20Mountain">Morosi's Mountain</a>. From an exposed position, on open ground, he carried in his arms a wounded corporal of the Cape Mounted Riflemen. The surgeon major then returned under severe enemy fire in order to dress the wounds of the other men of the storming party.
Later service.
He later achieved the rank of surgeon <a href="colonel">colonel</a> and, in March 1900 during the <a href="Second%20Boer%20War">Second Boer War</a> fighting at <a href="Aliwal%20North">Aliwal</a>, he is mentioned doing ambulance work, ferrying away the wounded under fire.
In November 1900 he was reported wounded following the occupation of <a href="Philippolis">Philippolis</a> by <a href="Lovat%20Scouts">Lovat Scouts</a> and <a href="Seaforth%20Highlanders">Seaforth Highlanders</a>
On 19 April 1901 he was appointed a companion of the <a href="Order%20of%20St%20Michael%20and%20St%20George">Order of St Michael and St George</a> He died in Ash, <a href="Hampshire">Hampshire</a> and is buried at <a href="Brookwood%20Cemetery">Brookwood Cemetery</a>.
The Medal.
In 1955 the Victoria Cross medal was bought at <a href="Sotheby%27s">Sotheby's</a> for the then record price of £300. It is now displayed at the <a href="Army%20Medical%20Services%20Museum">Army Medical Services Museum</a> in <a href="Mytchett">Mytchett</a>, <a href="Surrey">Surrey</a>.
